results.abstract: 1st satellite in long-delayed EROS program to be launched in May; known as ERTS-A, for Earth Resources Technology Satellite, will be 1,800-lb vehicle that will carry electronic remote sensing devices and high-resolution TV cameras to locate earth's natural resources; together with ERTS-B, which will be launched in '73, will develop a land and agr map of US, classify geologic and soil features and develop techniques for processing huge amts of earth data; specialists in remote electronic sensing who attended recent Cong conf on earth resources voiced criticism with pace and mgt of EROS program; contend that mgt has been divided among Interior, Agr and Commerce Depts and NASA, and that Defense Dept, which has spent large amts on mil sensors, has been uncooperative toward program; ex-Interior Sec S L Udall blames footdragging by NASA for program delay; says he tried as early as '65 to get NASA interested; says he proposed that Interior Dept would put up $2-million for program if NASA would put up $5-million but NASA refused; Udall's contention backed by series of lrs made public by HR Com on Science and Astronautics in '68 which indicated NASA officials were lukewarm toward program; one of current disputes involving EROS concerns Air Force refusal, apparently for security reasons, to allow use of new high-resolution camera; Repr Winn, member of HR Science Com, says EROS has been a stepchild of Apollo program and Govt agencies involved are still jealous of each other

headline.main: Satellite-Borne Dowsing Rod to Be Orbited in Spring

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Federal program to locate the earth's natural treasures with electronic dowsing rods carried aloft by satellites is finally scheduled to blast off this spring after years of delays and unending complaints, of bureaucratic...

byline.original: By RICHARD D. LYONSSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Federal program to locate the earth's natural treasures with electronic dowsing rods carried aloft by satellites is finally scheduled to blast off this spring after years of delays and unending complaints, of bureaucratic footdragging, and in-fighting.

results.snippet: Most of Stanley Kubrick's films are protests, motivated by a metaphysical hunger. "A Clockwork Orange" is no exception. What Professor Hoxie Neale Fairchild said of William Blake, the English poet, could be applied to Kubrick: "He saw that man's...
results.lead_paragraph: Most of Stanley Kubrick's films are protests, motivated by a metaphysical hunger. "A Clockwork Orange" is no exception. What Professor Hoxie Neale Fairchild said of William Blake, the English poet, could be applied to Kubrick: "He saw that man's brain had been shaping a world that was not fit for man's spirit to live in."

headline.main: Aussie Pacer Concludes A Long Journey Tonight

results.snippet: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 10 -- A horse that is flown a considerable distance, such as the 12,000-mile plane trip from New Zealand or Australia to this country, may find the going more taxing than an astronaut does on a flight to the moon.

byline.original: By LOUIS EFFRATSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 10 -- A horse that is flown a considerable distance, such as the 12,000-mile plane trip from New Zealand or Australia to this country, may find the going more taxing than an astronaut does on a flight to the moon.

results.abstract: NASA announces rugged area south of Taurus Mts and Litterow crater will be lunar landing site of Apollo 17 mission, last scheduled US manned flight to moon; scheduled launch date is Dec 6; scientists hope mission will gather data on moon's history; crew will be commanded by Capt Cernan; other crew members will be Dr H H Schmitt and Comdr Evans

headline.main: APOLLO 17 TO LAND IN A LUNAR VALLEY; Site Near Heights Chosen for Last Shot, Due Dec. 6

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -Apollo 17, the last scheduled United States manned flight to the moon, will have as its target a rugged area of steep mountains and dark valleys where scientists hope to find clues to the ancient lunar past.

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -Apollo 17, the last scheduled United States manned flight to the moon, will have as its target a rugged area of steep mountains and dark valleys where scientists hope to find clues to the ancient lunar past.

headline.main: Ten Years for Glenn and NASA

results.snippet: John H. Glenn Jr. and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are 10 years older today, and both find themselves in a period of transition that reflects how much has changed since the flight of Friendship 7, which put an American in orbit...
results.lead_paragraph: John H. Glenn Jr. and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are 10 years older today, and both find themselves in a period of transition that reflects how much has changed since the flight of Friendship 7, which put an American in orbit for the first time.

results.abstract: Gov Reagan says he would be protesting Nixon's visit to China if Nixon were a Dem, because, he says, Dems would be 'appeasement-minded'
results.snippet: Senator William Proxmire showed up at a committee hearing with gauze bandages covering his head, and made no bones about why. "On Tuesday night, Feb. 22, I began treatment for hair transplants," he said in a prepared statement.

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Smithsonian Institution is up, up and away with a spectacular balloon exhibit that dramatizes the history and adventure of man's first escapes from the planet earth.

byline.original: By NAN ROBERTSONSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Smithsonian Institution is up, up and away with a spectacular balloon exhibit that dramatizes the history and adventure of man's first escapes from the planet earth.
